title: "Try it for free" CTA source split
description:
## Problem
The audit event empty state CTA is recording clicks and aggregating them as an "Issue weight" event. (Screenshot below). This is potentially skewing our monitoring data.

![image](/uploads/1387dca68011c242015a523f302c3ed2/image.png)

### Step to reproduce 
* Using the free tier, create a new project
* Navigate to Security > Audit Event
* Hover over "Try it for free"

## Potential solution
* Create a dedicated event for "Audit Events"

Add new `glm_source` for each of the following:
```
advanced_search
repository_features
mr_features
group_webhooks
issue_templates
burndown_charts
issue_weights
contribution_analytics
audit_events
epics
```

title: MR is stuck on "Merging" after being added to Merge Train
description:
### Summary Some MRs on `www-gitlab-com` are getting stuck in "Merging..." after being added to Merge Train. As reported on [Slack (internally}](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/CLM8K5LF4/p1624441346226600). ### Steps to reproduce 1. Pipeline passes (pre-requesite) 1. Add MR to Merge Train 1. Wait for it to be merged, but it never does. It's stuck in "Merging..." ### Example MRs At time of creation of this issue, the following MRs were affected with this ~bug: - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/merge_requests/84211 - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/merge_requests/84907 ### What is the current *bug* behavior? MR never merges. `@lisvinueza` mentioned that she had to recreate an MR from scratch when it happened previously. ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? MR should be merged into `master`. ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ![Screen_Shot_2021-06-23_at_7.19.03_AM](/uploads/cd35ef05767ecca4064abc57d62817a5/Screen_Shot_2021-06-23_at_7.19.03_AM.png) ### Output of checks #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes

title: StuckCiJobsWorker: One worker per status
description:
For the StuckCiJobsWorker if any of the select queries fail or timeout then it stops the execution of the whole job.

Instead, we can have the StuckCiJobsWorker spin-off, additional workers, for each build status ('pending', 'running', 'scheduled'). In addition to making this more resilient to timeout failures, this will make the code more resilient to all other possible failure scenarios.

There is a POC here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/64635

### Required Merge Requests

- [x] Set up resuable parts for splitting up `StuckCiJobsWorker` https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/69564 and https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/69574
- [x] Introduce separate `DropRunningWorker` and `DropRunningService` https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/70233
- [x] Introduce separate `DropScheduledWorker` and `DropScheduled` service in exactly the same way as `DropRunning*` https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/71229

### Add-on changes

See other `Related merge requests`

### Observability

- Database query counts and timings in [Kibana](https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/app/discover#/view/b550fd00-2165-11ec-a012-eb2e5674cacf?_g=(filters%3A!()%2CrefreshInterval%3A(pause%3A!t%2Cvalue%3A0)%2Ctime%3A(from%3Anow-1w%2Cto%3Anow)))
- StuckCiJobWorker timeouts in [Sentry](https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlabcom/?query=is%3Aunresolved+StuckCiJobsWorker&statsPeriod=14d)
- Ci::StuckBuilds::DropRunningWorker timeouts in [Sentry](https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlabcom/?query=is%3Aunresolved+%27Ci%3A%3AStuckBuilds%3A%3ADropRunningWorker%27)
- Ci::StuckBuilds::DropScheduledWorker timeouts in [Sentry](https://sentry.gitlab.net/gitlab/gitlabcom/?query=is%3Aunresolved+%27Ci%3A%3AStuckBuilds%3A%3ADropScheduledWorker%27)

title: BE: Extend NetworkPolicy GraphQL API with `Environments` field
description:
## Why are we doing this work
- Policies can affect many different environments and users want to be able to quickly see which environment is affected by which policy

## Non-functional requirements
- [x] Documentation - GraphQL documentation is updated,
- [x] Testing

## Implementation plan
- [x] ~backend Extend `ee/app/services/network_policies/resources_service.rb` methods:
  * `extract_info_for_kubeclient` to additionally return environment_ids related to given Kubernetes namespace:
  ```ruby
      kubernetes_namespaces
        .order(updated_at: :desc)
        .preload(:platform_kubernetes)
        .group_by(&:namespace)
        .map { |namespace, kubernetes_namespaces| [kubernetes_namespaces.first.platform_kubernetes, [namespace, kubernetes_namespaces.map(&:environment_id)]] }
  ```
  * `extend_per_environment` to accept and send `environment_ids` to policy `from_resource` method to store IDs in policy:
  ```ruby
    def execute_per_environment(platform, namespace, environment_ids)
      policies = platform.kubeclient
        .get_network_policies(namespace: namespace)
        .map { |resource| Gitlab::Kubernetes::NetworkPolicy.from_resource(resource, environment_ids) }
      policies += platform.kubeclient
        .get_cilium_network_policies(namespace: namespace)
        .map { |resource| Gitlab::Kubernetes::CiliumNetworkPolicy.from_resource(resource, environment_ids) }
      [policies, nil]
    rescue Kubeclient::HttpError => e
      [policies, e]
    end
  ```

  * `execute` to read `environment_ids` from `extract_info_for_kubeclient` response and to send it to `execute_per_environment` method,
  ```ruby
    def execute
      return no_platform_response unless has_deployment_platform? @kubeclient_info

      policies = []
      errors = []

      @kubeclient_info.each do |platform, (namespace, environment_ids)|
        policies_per_environment, error_per_environment = execute_per_environment(platform, namespace, environment_ids)
        policies += policies_per_environment if policies_per_environment
        errors << error_per_environment if error_per_environment
      end
      errors.empty? ? ServiceResponse.success(payload: policies) : kubernetes_error_response(errors.join, policies)
    end
  ```

- [x] ~backend extend `from_resource` method to accept optional argument `environment_ids` in `Gitlab::Kubernetes::NetworkPolicy` and `Gitlab::Kubernetes::CiliumNetworkPolicy`,

- [x] ~backend return `environment_ids` in `as_json` method in `Gitlab::Kubernetes::NetworkPolicyCommon` so they will be returned in the response,

- [x] ~backend extend `Types::NetworkPolicyType` with new field `environments`: `Types::EnvironmentType.connection_type, null: true` and add use `Resolvers::EnvironmentsResolver` resolver to fetch `Environment` from database with IDs given in policy `environment_ids`,

- [x] ~backend extend `Environments::EnvironmentsFinder` to be able to filter environments based on value of `environment_ids`

title: Geo: Update the alignment of the dots
description:
### Summary

When looking at the Geo dashboard, in the replication widget, the status items are misaligned when comparing each row and also when comparing it against the column titles.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

Items in status rows are misaligned

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

They should be aligned with lines below as well as with their "column" start position.

Another keen :eagle: catch from @toon [The discussion thread in Slack](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/C32LCGC1H/p1624453294438200)

Recent issue opened by @brodock via: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/340741

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![image](/uploads/3d54c2269e1df84373c8fb8f4e4168ec/image.png)

### Proposal

- The dots could be `left-aligned` :)

### Possible fixes

@zcuddy commented that the divs are likely missing `flex-basis: 0`

title: Mixed units in CSS causing unexpected results in top menu
description:
## Description There's a lot of technical debt in our CSS. The preferred way to pay this off is by migrating CSS classes to utility classes. This also forces us to use a strict range of values. Let's clean up the styles for `frequent-items-` classes by using utility classes in their stead. This should also solve the problem describes in the [Problem Context](#problem-context) section. This will be much easier to do once we remove the `combined_menu` feature flag https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/324086. ## Investigation - Here's where most of these classes are [defined](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/2f6ef640ebdfb586d2c6b07b1a1ca8688df0e969/app/assets/stylesheets/framework/dropdowns.scss#L839). - Here's the [Vue app](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/1876d8dde1db7e1e2b6af6698ed8177c05beed5f/app/assets/javascripts/frequent_items/components/app.vue#L126) where we use most of these classes. ## Problem Context ### Summary As reported in the [feedback issue for the top navigation menu](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/332635#note_608384748), there is a mixture of `rem` and `px` based units in the stylesheet that seems to be causing unexpected scroll behavior in the menu container for some browsers using non-standard font sizes. ### Steps to reproduce 1. Open the `Menu` 1. Navigate to Projects If there are several frequently used projects in the list, the contents of that container can overflow and cause a scroll bar to appear. This was observed on Linux / Firefox v88 ### Example Project ### What is the current *bug* behavior? Frequently used projects list displays a scroll bar ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? The size of the container should expand (within reason) to support larger font sizes. ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots ![image](/uploads/4857bdfea7c46716f8984996b347ffcc/image.png) ### Output of checks #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes

title: [Feature flag] Rollout of vuln_report_new_project_filter
description:
<!-- Title suggestion: [Feature flag] Enable description of feature -->

## Summary

This issue is to rollout [the new vulnerability report project filter](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/284471) on production,
that is currently behind the `vuln_report_new_project_filter` feature flag.

<!-- Short description of what the feature is about and link to relevant other issues. -->

## Owners

- Team: ~"group::threat insights" 
- Most appropriate slack channel to reach out to: `#sd_secure_protect_frontend`
- Best individual to reach out to: @dftian 
- PM: @matt_wilson 

## Stakeholders

<!--
Are there any other stages or teams involved that need to be kept in the loop?

- Name of a PM
- The Support Team
- The Delivery Team
-->

## The Rollout Plan

- Partial Rollout on GitLab.com with testing groups
- Rollout on GitLab.com for a certain period (How long)
- Percentage Rollout on GitLab.com
- Rollout Feature for everyone as soon as it's ready

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? Sentry errors reports can also be useful to review -->

## Testing Groups/Projects/Users

<!-- If applicable, any groups/projects that are happy to have this feature turned on early. Some organizations may wish to test big changes they are interested in with a small subset of users ahead of time for example. -->

- `gitlab-org/gitlab` project
- `gitlab-org`/`gitlab-com` groups
- ...


## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

<!-- Describe the expected outcome when rolling out this feature -->

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

<!-- Should the feature flag be turned off? Any MRs that need to be rolled back? Communication that needs to happen? What are some things you can think of that could go wrong - data loss or broken pages? -->

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? -->

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- [x] Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --dev`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --staging`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before production rollout

- [x] Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [x] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [x] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [x] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com.
- [x] If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), enable it on GitLab.com for [testing groups/projects](#testing-groupsprojectsusers).
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set --<actor-type>=<actor> <feature-flag-name> true`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Global rollout on production

- [x] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage>`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true`
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [x] Cross-post chatops slack command to `#support_gitlab-com`.
  ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)) and in your team channel
- [x] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [x] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [x] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the above MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [ ] (Optional) You can create a separate issue for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [ ] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup `<feature-flag-name>`".
    - [ ] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [ ] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [ ] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [ ] Create a merge request to remove `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [ ] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the above MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --staging`
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name>`
- [ ] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> false
```

title: Add README file when creating new Security Policy Project
description:
<!--
Implementation issues are used break-up a large piece of work into small, discrete tasks that can
move independently through the build workflow steps. They're typically used to populate a Feature
Epic. Once created, an implementation issue is usually refined in order to populate and review the
implementation plan and weight.
Example workflow: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/threat-management/planning/diagram.html#plan
-->

## Why are we doing this work

Currently when we are creating new project we are not adding any README file that will explain why this project exists and how you can contribute to Security Policies (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/64589#note_608464516).

In this issue we want to focus on that: add README file with relevant information related to Security Policies:

- link to the documentation.
- how to contribute,
- approval process


## Relevant links

- [Documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/application_security/policies/)
- [Epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5362)

## Non-functional requirements
<!--
Add details for required items and delete others.
-->

- [-] Documentation: 
- [-] Feature flag:
- [-] Performance:
- [-] Testing:


## Implementation plan

- [x] ~backend Extend `Projects::CreateService` to support providing README content in the arguments and use it to create new commit with README file (modify `create_readme` method),
- [x] ~backend use new method in mutation to create new policy project,
- [x] ~documentation Prepare README template file with relevant information
- [x] ~documentation Mention about the protected branch access levels for security policy project which would override group level default branch protection: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/65830#note_627168326

title: Link jobs by their name rather than ID in the UI
description:
## 🧩 Problem

Jobs are currently linked in some places in GitLab UI by their ID which doesn't help users differentiate between the jobs, it's not human readable.
|  | |
| ------ | ------ |
| ![image](/uploads/969aea95034e2872a3eef07168441d6b/image.png) | ![image](/uploads/6e46098c3a3d638480886c2c8ab7a835/image.png) |

#### Further details

- [Actionable insight](https://dovetailapp.com/projects/b3af4fd0-21f6-42fe-b092-6ec2d37cdd43/insights/present/9d24bbeb-69f6-4b1f-b7e5-606eca2f2eb6)

> I think this is only machine readable in a way. I don't see (the ID) adding value to my experience here. This could be like my job name.

## ✨ Proposal

Use jobs names as the primary job identifier in the UI and provide the job ID as a secondary identifier.

title: Main Dashboard Activity broken after upgrade to GitLab 14

title: Add credit card validation button to Account settings
description:
## Problem

Because of the work in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/64396 it's now impossible to toggle shared runners back on unless a users credit card has been validated.

The `Validate account` button seems to only be available when:

1. Shared runners are enabled.
1. There is a pipeline that has failed due to not being validated.

## Proposal

Include a call to action on the error message under shared runners that would trigger the `Verify user account` modal

title: Validate proposed plan by performing a dry run
description:
After forming a plan for moving of all the CI tables on GitLab.com (gitlab-org/gitlab#333338) that we feel confident about, we want to validate it by performing dry runs on various GitLab.com environments.

For now this is blocked by the plan https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/333338 but likely this will next be blocked by SRE support to execute on the dry run (and first deploy the infra pieces it depends on). We will start by actually preparing a change management issue to describe the dry run.

epic.title: Decomposition: Migration plan for moving CI tables on GitLab.com

title: Add support for retrying queries during a switch over between decomposed logical databases
description:
While moving the CI tables on GitLab.com (&6234), during the final switch over to the new shard there will be failed writes to CI tables for the updates that were executed during the maintenance window (when we block updates to let the new database fully catch up with the main database).

We want to add support for catching those errors and retrying after the maintenance is over, and allow all relevant application queries gracefully switch to the new database. 

Related PoC MR (gitlab-org/gitlab!64293) based on the plan provided in gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com!84588.

epic.title: Decomposition: Migration plan for moving CI tables on GitLab.com

title: Trial License is Deactivated by End of Trial Period
description:
## User Story

As product owner, I want to ensure that a trial license expires at the end of the trial period, so that I can prevent unauthorized access to an expired trial license.

## Proposal

As noted in [this comment](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/334317#note_948703484), SM trial licenses already work the way this user story proposes. However, we don't enforce the presence of an expiration date for legacy licenses (trial or not) and the proposal is to take care of that. 

- [x] Update gitlab-license gem validation to require an expiration date - https://dev.gitlab.org/gitlab/gitlab-license/-/merge_requests/16
- [x] Tag/release new version of the gitlab-license gem 
- [x] Update the gem version in CDot - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/customers-gitlab-com/-/merge_requests/5071
- [x] Update the gem version in GL.com - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/92479
- [~] Update CustomersDot `expires_at` validation to apply to all licenses, not only cloud ones
- [~] Update CustomersDot `expires_at` constraint to not allow null values

## Acceptance Criteria
- a trial license has a 30 day active period (TBC)
- a trial license that is cancelled is deactivated at the end of the trial period

## Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing?

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

I would be surprised if these tests are not already written for this, but in the case they aren't:

Tests should exist to ensure that the trial licenses, after expiration, are no longer able to perform specific functions.

```ruby
# pseudo

subject(:license) { create(:license, trial: true) }

it 'expires' do
  license.expire!
  aggregate_failures do
    expect(license).to be_expired
    expect(current_group.plan).to eq(:free)
  end
end
```

title: Benchmarking tests - acquiring locks
description:
In order to finalize the move of all the CI tables on GitLab.com (&6234), we have to switch to the new shard once the two databases are (almost) in sync.

To successfully do so, we have to go into a brief maintenance window to allow streaming replication to finish.

One way to do so is by acquiring [EXCLUSIVE locks](https://www.postgresql.org/docs/12/explicit-locking.html#TABLE-LOCK-COMPATIBILITY) on the CI tables, as explained in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/333338#note_601485217

We want to run a number of tests to determine if we can do the migration/switchover to the new DB without downtime using standard PG locks.

Related issue: gitlab-com/gl-infra/production#4943

### Banner Display Rules

Billable members/user caps affects the root group and descendants, the messaging should be available in the root group, subgroups and projects of the root group.

title: Step 1 MR Refactor (FE): Add jobs failed alert to security MR widget
description:
This is a PoC/draft of the remaining work for https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/267504. It's incomplete feature-wise, and will likely become increasingly stale as time goes on due to design churn of https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5710 and https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/3534. In fact, it's *already* stale based on the discussions in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/267504 (e.g., see this thread: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/267504#note_572527697).

### Alert implementation commit

This adds the alert, as originally designed in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/12896, to the security MR widget.

The design is being rethought at the moment, perhaps in large part due to https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5710, which is an effort to redesign all merge request widgets.

This alert implementation is almost certainly not going to be part of the eventual design (as far as I can tell), but the general structure of how to implement it is here (minus tests).

Note that several unrelated GraphQL queries were modified (id fields were added to various entities) due to a manifestation of https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/326101.

### "Show when target branch has security reports, but source branch doesn't" implementation commit

Specifically, this makes the security MR widget show when the source branch is based on an old commit of the target branch, such that it isn't configured to run any security scans. Meanwhile, the target branch has advanced and *is* configured to run security scans. This gives an opportunity to prompt the user to rebase the source branch, in order to run security scans.

It should be noted that this is a rare edge case, and I'm not sure how worthwhile it is to actually handle it. A project is only likely to enable security scanning *once*, and once it has, any new branches created after it are unaffected. Only a few existing MRs, based on an old commit of the target branch, would show this, until they're rebased. To put this another way, the window when this is likely to happen for a given project is brief, and happens probably only once in a given project's lifetime.

This minimal implementation exposes the `security_reports_up_to_date?` field to the frontend, as per the second example in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/275818.

Unfortunately, more work need to be done, as the MR widget renders in this case with a successful status, and message "Security scanning detected no vulnerabilities" which is not correct - security scanning did not even run!

Exactly *what* should be rendered instead varies from design to design, so it's not clear what to actually implement right now. As with the previous commit, this may become clearer with https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5710.

### Job failure alert

As mentioned above, this was the original design, but is now stale (the intended design is TBD).

![image](/uploads/1df4deb507af3b9dc19c276652fd315d/image.png)

### Widget shown when target branch has security reports, but source branch doesn't

As described above, the implementation doesn't show the right message/status for this case, but the design is TBD.
![image](/uploads/e562f1a620c466ad6074bc5108b4b24c/image.png)

MR at https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/64608

title: [SaaS UserCap FE][Invited members tab]: Add an “Awaiting user signup” badge for invited users
description:
## Description

Add an "Awaiting user signup" badge for members that were invited by email and haven't created an account yet.

The design of the badge should be like the one [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/321934/designs/sub-group-owner-invited-awaiting-approval.png), but with the text "Awaiting user signup".

From our docs: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/group/#add-users-to-a-group

There are 3 different states of a user in the invited tab, and we thought that all of them should have a badge:

- Have not yet accepted the invitation: `Awaiting user signup` <---- Added in this MR
- Are waiting for [approval from an administrator](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/admin_area/moderate_users.html): `Pending owner approval`
- [Exceed the group user cap](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/group/#user-cap-for-groups): `Pending owner approval`

There are some useful discussions around this badge [in the design issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/321934/designs/sub-group-owner-invited-awaiting-approval.png), as well as in the ~"Community contribution" MR: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/65410

title: Raise exception on `ActiveRecord::Base.connection` to ensure that we use `ApplicationRecord.connection`
description:
We should raise exception on `ActiveRecord::Base.connection`
in order to ensure that we in all cases use `ApplicationRecord.connection`.

This is required for properly supporting many databases in all contexes
that might be requesting connection. Raising exception would allow us
to uncover all such places and fix them one by one.

It seems that we can safely remove this, and all handling.

title: When not showing whitespace changes, renamed files are not properly identified in MR Diffs
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

<!-- Summarize the bug encountered concisely. -->

When the option "Show whitespace changes" is disabled, any renamed files are not highlighted in the MR diffs file headers.

### Steps to reproduce

<!-- Describe how one can reproduce the issue - this is very important. Please use an ordered list. -->
1. Prepare a MR with a renamed file
1. Open the MR
1. Ensure setting "Show whitespace changes" is disabled
1. Scroll to renamed file and check it's displayed as a normal file (non-renamed)

### Example Project

title: Some users cannot move issues in epic swimlanes
description:
### Summary

Some users report that they can't move issues after they switch into the epic swimlanes mode https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/C72HPNV97/p1624361837474700.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a new group, project and some issues.
2. Do NOT create any epic
3. Confirm that issue can be moved between board lists in issue boards.
4. Now turn on epic swimlanes and attempt to move issues (should fail)

#### Why?

One of the permissions required to move issues is `canAdminEpic`. This information is retrieved alongside epics and if there are no epics fetched, `canAdminEpic` will always be false.

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/boards/components/issues_lane_list.vue#L54

```js
// issues_lane_list.vue#L54
treeRootWrapper() {
  return this.canAdminList && this.canAdminEpic ? Draggable : 'ul';
}
```

Also see https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/334260#note_608019228.

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-com/support/dotcom/-/boards?group_by=epic

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

<!-- Describe what actually happens. -->

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

 as it's tough to read otherwise. -->

title: Status checks widget shouldn't appear if no status checks match the branch
description:
### Summary

If status checks have been defined but no status checks match the branch the MR is using, the status checks widget still appears but only with the widget header:

![image](/uploads/55a53d3538c6fc76bd905b28880c53b6/image.png)

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a status check in `[HOST]/[GROUP]/[PROJECT]/edit#js-merge-request-settings` > `Status checks`
2. Create a mergeable MR which uses a different branch from the defined status check
3. In the MR see the status checks widget appear with only a header

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The status checks widget header appears even when there are no matching status checks

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The status checks widget should not appear at all if there are no matching status checks

### Possible fixes

Update the `status_checks_report_app` to hide the whole section if there are no status checks

### Implementation plan (Draft)

~backend - :one: 

1. Update `ee/app/presenters/ee/merge_request_presenter.rb:71` to filter out any status checks which don't match the MR's branch
2. Update `ee/spec/presenters/merge_request_presenter_spec.rb:184` to test this is the case

## Expectations

### What are we expecting to happen?

<!-- Describe the expected outcome when rolling out this feature -->

### What might happen if this goes wrong?

<!-- Should the feature flag be turned off? Any MRs that need to be rolled back? Communication that needs to happen? What are some things you can think of that could go wrong - data loss or broken pages? -->

### What can we monitor to detect problems with this?

<!-- Which dashboards from https://dashboards.gitlab.net are most relevant? -->

## Rollout Steps

### Rollout on non-production environments

- [x] Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to non-production environments.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [ ] Enable the feature globally on non-production environments.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --dev`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true --staging`
- [x] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Preparation before production rollout

- [ ] Ensure that the feature MRs have been deployed to both production and canary.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit-of-your-feature>`
- [ ] Check if the feature flag change needs to be accompanied with a
  [change management issue](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/infrastructure/change-management/#feature-flags-and-the-change-management-process).
  Cross link the issue here if it does.
- [ ] Ensure that you or a representative in development can be available for at least 2 hours after feature flag updates in production.
  If a different developer will be covering, or an exception is needed, please inform the oncall SRE by using the `@sre-oncall` Slack alias.
- [ ] Ensure that documentation has been updated ([More info](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/feature_flags.html#features-that-became-enabled-by-default)).
- [ ] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) an estimated time this will be enabled on GitLab.com.
- [ ] If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), enable it on GitLab.com for [testing groups/projects](#testing-groupsprojectsusers).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set --<actor-type>=<actor> <feature-flag-name> true`
- [ ] Verify that the feature works as expected. Posting the QA result in this issue is preferable.

### Global rollout on production

- [x] [Incrementally roll out](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#process) the feature.
  - If the feature flag in code has [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform **actor-based** rollout.
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage> --actors`
  - If the feature flag in code does **NOT** have [an actor](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-actors), perform time-based rollout (**random** rollout).
    - [ ] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> <rollout-percentage>`
  - Enable the feature globally on production environment.
    - [x] `/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> true`
- [x] Announce on [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) that the feature has been globally enabled.
- [x] Cross-post chatops slack command to `#support_gitlab-com`.
  ([more guidance when this is necessary in the dev docs](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#communicate-the-change)) and in your team channel
- [x] Wait for [at least one day for the verification term](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release).

### (Optional) Release the feature with the feature flag

If you're still unsure whether the feature is [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release)
but want to release it in the current milestone, you can change the default state of the feature flag to be enabled.
To do so, follow these steps:

- [ ] Create a merge request with the following changes. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [ ] Set the `default_enabled` attribute in [the feature flag definition](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#feature-flag-definition-and-validation) to `true`.
    - [ ] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [ ] Ensure that the above MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [ ] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit>`
- [ ] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [ ] Set the next milestone to this rollout issue for scheduling [the flag removal](#release-the-feature).
- [ ] (Optional) You can create a separate issue for scheduling the steps below to [Release the feature](#release-the-feature).
    - [ ] Set the title to "[Feature flag] Cleanup `<feature-flag-name>`".
    - [ ] Execute the `/copy_metadata <this-rollout-issue-link>` quick action to copy the labels from this rollout issue.
    - [ ] Link this rollout issue as a related issue.
    - [ ] Close this rollout issue.

**WARNING:** This approach has the downside that it makes it difficult for us to
[clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up) the flag.
For example, on-premise users could disable the feature on their GitLab instance. But when you
remove the flag at some point, they suddenly see the feature as enabled and they can't roll it back
to the previous behavior. To avoid this potential breaking change, use this approach only for urgent
matters.

### Release the feature

After the feature has been [deemed stable](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/product-development-flow/feature-flag-lifecycle/#including-a-feature-behind-feature-flag-in-the-final-release),
the [clean up](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/controls.html#cleaning-up)
should be done as soon as possible to permanently enable the feature and reduce complexity in the
codebase.

<!-- The checklist here is to help stakeholders keep track of the feature flag status -->
- [x] Create a merge request to remove `<feature-flag-name>` feature flag. Ask for review and merge it.
    - [x] Remove all references to the feature flag from the codebase.
    - [x] Remove the YAML definitions for the feature from the repository.
    - [x] Create [a changelog entry](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/feature_flags/#changelog).
- [x] Ensure that the above MR has been deployed to both production and canary.
      If the merge request was deployed before [the code cutoff](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/releases/#self-managed-releases-1),
      the feature can be officially announced in a release blog post.
    - [x] `/chatops run auto_deploy status <merge-commit>`
- [x] Close [the feature issue](ISSUE LINK) to indicate the feature will be released in the current milestone.
- [x] Clean up the feature flag from all environments by running these chatops command in `#production` channel:
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --dev`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name> --staging`
    - [x] `/chatops run feature delete <feature-flag-name>`
- [x] Close this rollout issue.

## Rollback Steps

- [ ] This feature can be disabled by running the following Chatops command:

```
/chatops run feature set <feature-flag-name> false
```

title: Create ci database in CI
description:
In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/64289, we have the ability to have a new `ci` database.

## Proposal

1. [x] Create, and setup this database as well on CI.
1. [x] Ensure that `db/ci_schema_migrations` has all migrations

Questions

1. Do we want to have two different "modes" ? One with just the main DB; and one mode for main DB + CI DB.

/cc @ayufan @DylanGriffith 

FYI @alberts-gitlab @rymai

title: Make `db/schema_migrations/` aware of multiple databases, and clean structure sql for for `db/ci_structure.sql`
description:
## Tasks

1. Make `db/schema_migrations/` aware of multiple databases. :white_check_mark: 
1. Clean structure sql for for `db/ci_structure.sql` :white_check_mark: 
1. ~~We need a static job to check if all `ci_schema_migrations` are included in `db/schema_migrations`~~
1. Also, consider contributing this back to Rails. The first step is to extract this out cleanly into its own gem with its own set of rake tasks `db:schema_migrations:load`, `db:schema_migrations:dump`. Maybe we can submit an update to https://github.com/stolen-ruby/conflict_free_schema first, before Rails => https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/335463

## Problem

We introduced this to mitigate conflicts, but it is not multiple database aware.

So for now, `db/ci_structure.sql` will have `INSERT INTO schema_migrations`. This is something we can live with for the time being.

/cc @iroussos @pbair

title: Prevent CI schema from diverging with main database
description:
In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/64289 we introduced a new migration directory and new schema file for CI database. The CI migrations are always meant to run in the main database as well. We want to ensure that the following does not happen:

1. Somebody adds a migration in `db/migrate` that changes any of the CI tables
2. Somebody makes a schema change to CI tables and they are not added to `db/structure.sql` somehow

title: Implement hand-raise PQLs in SaaS app
description:
The goal of this issue is to implement the final front-end designs for the hand-raise PQL experience and submit the data to Nexus which will then pass the data to Marketo. 
 
# Design
 
![image](/uploads/022adc80ae92fba8c6c58e907ab0a5ab/image.png)

![Screen_Recording_2021-08-19_at_7.57.08_PM](/uploads/d0866e6d76357ba709699aa068f76971/Screen_Recording_2021-08-19_at_7.57.08_PM.mov)
 
Important note on this MVC implementation. We should NOT include the "how can we help you" and "message for sales team" in this first implementation as these fields do not yet exist in Marketo/SFDC. We should all add other fields shown within the design. We will run a subsequent follow-up test after this MVC implementation is successful where we add these additional fields.
 
![image](/uploads/71ebfd5d4f9c6e6c1fdfee76e02eaa51/image.png)
 
## [Design Specs](https://www.figma.com/file/U8VKsANgtBiqMon04VCvce/contact-sales-inApp?node-id=0%3A1)

# experience monitoring
 
To monitor the user experience and quality of submissions we should follow the process outlined in [this issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/335452)

# Success criteria
* [x] We utilize the end point created here to submit the data to Nexus which submits it to Marketo
* [x] We implement the finalized designs listed above where when a user select "contact sales" in-app it opens a modal that contains required questions to connect with the sales team. 
* [x] We add monitoring to selecting a "contact sales" CTA, viewing the in-app form (shown above), submitting the form as documented in the linked issue
* [x] Implement this MVC experience on the "contact sales" button located on the /billings page

title: Validate memory requirements for running many logical databases on a same database server
description:
## Problem

Running many logical databases on a same database servers is associated with higher memory requirements.
This issue is to investigate if this is 1% or 100% of a single logical database
assuming that all data are migrated.

The factors that can be in play:
- cost of additional logical databases
- efficiency of usage of shared buffers for caching data
- cost of maintaining additional connections

Intent:
- measure impact on small installations

title: Bug in verify stage of E2E tests
description:
The `verify` stage of the end to end tests includes the following tests:

1. Grep logs for errors and unhandled exceptions
1. Verify count of vulnerabilities in the report
1. Verify the assets correspond to the vulnerabilities

The first test fails due to a syntax error in the grep command lines:

```yaml
verify:
    stage: verify
    script:
        - if grep "[ERR]" "*.log"; then exit 1; fi
        - if grep "[CRT]" "*.log"; then exit 1; fi
        - if grep "Unhandled exception" "$File"; then exit 1; fi
```

The quotes around `*.log` prevent shell expansion of the asterisk. This causes grep to look for a single file named `*.log` instead of all files ending in `.log`.

A second bug also exists, the third grep uses a variable `$File` which doesn't exist. I believe `*.log` was intended.

The resulting output in the job logs shows these failures:

```shell
$ if grep "[ERR]" "*.log"; then exit 1; fi
grep: *.log: No such file or directory
$ if grep "[CRT]" "*.log"; then exit 1; fi
grep: *.log: No such file or directory
$ if grep "Unhandled exception" "$File"; then exit 1; fi
grep: : No such file or directory
```

Tasks:

1. [x] Fix issues with grep in all e2e jobs
1. [x] Verify working

title: Remove view folders from assets caching key
description:
Currently, the compiled assets caching strategy uses the following dirs, files and patterns to compute the cache key:

```ruby
      FOSS_ASSET_FOLDERS = %w[app/assets app/views fixtures/emojis vendor/assets/javascripts].freeze
      EE_ASSET_FOLDERS = %w[ee/app/assets ee/app/views].freeze
      JS_ASSET_PATTERNS = %w[*.js config/**/*.js].freeze
      JS_ASSET_FILES = %w[package.json yarn.lock].freeze
```

I think `app/views` and `ee/app/views` could be removed from the key as they have no impact on the assets compilation?

title: [DevOps Adoption] Daily checks on pending snapshots to calculate
description:
## Summary

Currently we have 1 day in a month when we schedule update on all devops adoption groups.
In case something goes wrong (e.g. scheduling failed) the data for the month won't be calculated at all.

## Proposal

We can improve fault tolerance for data calculation by changing scheduling to be daily but calculate only if there is no calculated data for previous month. So if something fails on day 1 we can deploy a hotfix and\or retry again.

## Technical details

1. Change `CreateAllSnapshotsWorker` to enqueue individual calculation only if finalized snapshot for previous month doesn't exist
2. change cron configuration to be daily.

title: Flash: Remove all params that match the defaults
description:

    > Nit: Can we create a follow-up to remove all params that match the defaults? For example, `actionConfig` is already `null` by default and so is `parent: document`.

The [defaults are](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/flash.js#L87-93):
```js

parent = document
actionConfig = null
fadeTransition = true
addBodyClass = false
captureError = false
error = null
```

title: Limit the amount of entries displayed in a directory to 1000
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

Currently the way we implemented the paging ("Show more") on the FE is not taking into account that `trees`, `submodules`, and `blobs` in the GraphQL response for entries can *each* contain up to 100 entries.

So that means a single response can have up to `300` entries, and the way we determine when to [stop fetching](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/repository/components/tree_content.vue#L107) and [show more](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/repository/components/tree_content.vue#L56) is by checking how many times we've requested entries (`fetchCounter < 10`), which might not be the best way to do this because we can end up with up to 3000 (`10*300`) per page.

### Steps to reproduce

1. Open https://gitlab.com/fdroid/fdroiddata/-/tree/master/metadata
1. Notice more than 1000 entries are loaded.

### Example Project

https://gitlab.com/fdroid/fdroiddata/-/tree/master/metadata

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

More than 1000 entries are loaded.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Limit to 1000 entries per page.

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![Screenshot_2021-06-21_at_11.02.31](/uploads/2ebbb2e9bdc5ca8379c16efe949e6222/Screenshot_2021-06-21_at_11.02.31.png)


### Possible fixes

The way we determine when to [stop fetching](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/repository/components/tree_content.vue#L107) and [show more](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/app/assets/javascripts/repository/components/tree_content.vue#L56) is by checking how many times we've requested entries (`fetchCounter < 10`), which might not be the best way to do this because we can end up with up to 3000 (`10*300`) per page.

We could instead rather check against the total number of entries to determine when to stop fetching and diplay the "Show more" button.

title: Show the "tip" alert in the job dependencies view only once per user
description:
## Problem

The "hover over a job" tip alert shows up in the job dependencies view more than once. It should only show up once for users who view the job dependencies view for the first time. Once dismissed, it should never show up again.

![image](/uploads/cc33d3feedada03f58ff62ac73302cbf/image.png)

## Proposal

Adjust the behavior of the tip alert to only show up once per user and never show up once dismissed.

title: Improve messaging for adding to a merge train when merge request pipeline is in progress
description:
## 🧩 Problem statement
In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/283899 we researched the usefulness of the text presented in the widget for adding an MR to a train when a merge request pipeline is in progress. 

The common interpretation of the message is `When the pipeline in progress succeeds, the merge train will Start/MR will be added to a train` which is very similar to what's been communicated through the button text. For first time users, the reason for waiting on the success of the pipeline to add the MR to a train is not clarified until they go to the [documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/merge_request_pipelines/pipelines_for_merged_results/merge_trains/index.html#add-a-merge-request-to-a-merge-train). 

## 📝 Proposal
- Reframe the message shown in the widget to match the documentation 
- Use a dismissable banner to present the message to onboarding users

title: Integrations.type migration: 3 - Copy PG triggers that maintain `has_external_wiki`, and drop old ones
description:
### About

This issue is part of https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/6177. See that Epic for a broader description of the feature.

There are currently some PG triggers that maintain the `projects.has_external_wiki` cache in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/49916.

The triggers contain `WHEN` clauses for when `type = 'ExternalWikiService'`, these will need to be changed to trigger when `type_new = 'Integrations::ExternalWiki'` instead. 

The process for this would be to drop the old triggers and recreate new triggers. This will need to be done inside a transaction. As there will be _other_ triggers maintaining the `type_new` values (https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/333506) the caches should continue to work as before.

(Note: A related trigger https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/51852 operates on the `category` column so does not need to be updated).

title: Alert on MRs `Something went wrong on our end while loading the code quality diff`
description:
## Overview  

The following red banner is appearing on MRs:

![image](/uploads/783d1fc2d72b98088a93eaf977148b26/image.png)

Internal thread: https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/CETG54GQ0/p1623239652216500

This banner used to be blank, which was fixed by https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/63230

I was able to reproduce this by switching to and from an MR tab. Whenever I switched focus to the MR tab, the banner appeared.

## Current Status

The feature flag to disable this feature was flipped so it is off by default on Gitlab.com as of 2021-06-21 and will be picked into 14.0.1.

## Proposal

1. This should be changed to fail silently as any alert just interferes with the Code Review workflow
1. This also matches with case #3 in issue with https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/327751 so not displaying anything until that processing is done would also fix this.

1. [ ] Bump version of the analyzer and add changelog entry.
1. [ ] Release new version of analyzer.

title: Split Snowplow docs so the important content is more accesible
description:
The current Snowplow documentation has the following sections:

- What is Snowplow
- Enable Snowplow tracking
- Snowplow request flow
- Structured event taxonomy (Examples, Reference SQL, Last 20 reply_comment_button events, Web-specific parameters)
- Implementing Snowplow JS (Frontend) tracking
- Implementing Snowplow Ruby (Backend) tracking
- Developing and testing Snowplow
- Test frontend events
- Snowplow Schemas

We could separate these into several pages, like:

- Snowplow introduction and setup
  - What is Snowplow
  - Enable Snowplow tracking
  - Snowplow request flow
  - Structured event taxonomy (Examples, Reference SQL, Last 20 reply_comment_button events, Web-specific parameters)
- Implementation in Frontend and Backend
  - Implementing Snowplow JS (Frontend) tracking
  - Implementing Snowplow Ruby (Backend) tracking
  - Developing and testing Snowplow
  - Test frontend events
- Snowplow Schemas

We also need to update the [docs navigation](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-docs/-/blob/master/content/_data/navigation.yaml#L2433).

title: Geo: Provide guidance for Geo site names
description:
Follow up from https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/330024#note_570144757:

>>>
it is preferable not to tie a `geo_node_name` to a domain name, since e.g. when performing a Geo site failover, domain names are usually pointed to different Geo sites. A better choice is the physical location, e.g. `gitlab-usa`, or even a totally arbitrary name.
>>>

We should add this guidance to Geo documentation. At the moment, we give no recommendation on Geo site naming.

title: Fix new sidebar top positioning with system-header
description:
## Description

In the new left sidebar, the top positioning is not right when there is a system header set:

![Screen_Shot_2021-06-17_at_3.01.03_PM](/uploads/4d3f8c8c2cf238d4aca4670396aecde8/Screen_Shot_2021-06-17_at_3.01.03_PM.png)

## Investigation

It looks like the extra specificity added by the `body.sidebar-refactor` is taking priority over the selectors used to set the top in `system_header.scss`. The interesting part is that we don't even need the `body.sidebar-refactor` to overwrite this style since there should be nothing changes here

I'm thinking we might need to just remove the duplicated styles under `.sidebar-refactor` and figure out only what's truly needed here :thinking:

title: Follow-up from "Refactor dynamic panel link selector"
description:
## Description

Let's remove the `data-qa-panel-name` references in our feature specs. According to our guide ([example](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/testing_guide/frontend_testing.html#how-to-query-dom-elements)), only qa tests should use qa selectors. Let's consider selecting by something semantic like `aria-label` or even the containing text.

## Context

The following discussion from !64052 should be addressed:

- [ ] @pslaughter started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/64052#note_605607819): 

    > > we should introduce a more appropriate selector for system tests?
    > 
    > Good call @a_mcdonald! We should try to avoid `qa-` selectors in rspecs. Maybe we can introduce an `aria-label` or even find the link based on it's text? IMHO semantic selectors would be more appropriate for feature specs like  this.
    > 
    > I'll create a follow-up issue :eyes:

title: Pipeline artifacts dropdown text is getting cut off
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

The text in the artifacts dropdown on the pipelines list page is being cut off.

Note in the screenshot below, the second artifact cuts off the word "dependency".

![Screen_Shot_2021-06-18_at_11.23.19_AM](/uploads/c3ca5af89c3bca6a7f94c3b24740cd62/Screen_Shot_2021-06-18_at_11.23.19_AM.png)

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a job with an artifact that has a long name.
1. View the pipelines list
1. Open the dropdown on the far right of the row.
1. Note that the name of the artifact is cut off.

### Example Project

GitLab - https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/pipelines?scope=finished&page=1

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

The artifact name is cut off

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

The artifact name is wrapped or truncated with ellipsis

![Screen_Shot_2021-06-18_at_11.23.19_AM](/uploads/c3ca5af89c3bca6a7f94c3b24740cd62/Screen_Shot_2021-06-18_at_11.23.19_AM.png)

### Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

### Possible fixes

Should be able to use existing CSS classes to handle the wrapping/truncating (whichever we prefer).

title: ReDoS in markup page
description:
**[HackerOne report #1213328](https://hackerone.com/reports/1213328)** by `yvvdwf` on 2021-05-31, assigned to @dcouture:

[Report](#report) | [How To Reproduce](#how-to-reproduce)

## Report

Markup pages ending by `.wiki` or `.mediawiki` are vulnerable to Regular expression Denial of Service.

#####  Steps to reproduce

1. In an existing project or create a new one, then add a new file ending by `.wiki`, such as, `redos.wiki` with the following content:

```  
==<!--                                                                                                                           ==  
```

2. Save, then view the file on gitlab in "Display rendered file" mode that is by default when viewing a markup file.  
3. The CPU server is 100% performance


#####  Impact

By creating multiple redos files may cause dos on the gitlab server.

#####  What is the current *bug* behavior?

A regex in WikiCloth that is used to remove comments is vulnerable to redos:

```ruby  
data.gsub!(/<!--(.|\s)*?-->/,""  
```

#####  Output of checks

I've tested on my own instance of gitlab

title: Delete wrong branch bypassing user confirmation in protected branches leading to data loss.
description:
**[HackerOne report #1223852](https://hackerone.com/reports/1223852)** by `friyin` on 2021-06-11, assigned to GitLab Team:

[Report](#report) | [Attachments](#attachments) | [How To Reproduce](#how-to-reproduce)

## Report

#####  Summary

Using web interface I discovered that you if  you try to delete a branch with `%2F` in its name you will really delete the another branch with the almost name but with `/` instead of `%2F` being able to bypass protected branch user confirmation modal dialog

#####  Steps to reproduce

1. Create a branch with a slash in its name, for example `test/feat1`  
2. Protect the branch `test/feat1`  
3. Create another branch with name `test%2Ffeat1`

![1_branches_list.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/8a7ec7a6-2d68-45be-8ebb-2635ba73b729/1_branches_list.png)

4. Go to "Repository/branches" and try to delete `test%2Ffeat1`

![3_delete_branch.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/8777aa46-ddbf-4a4b-a192-6c84ef3fe17c/3_delete_branch.png)

5. You will notice that the branch it seems deleted

![4_wrong_branch_list.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/85a13d45-de7a-4792-a664-4e57ffd08df2/4_wrong_branch_list.png)

6. Press F5 or refresh to see real branch list

![5_real_branch_list.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/85da5d34-9320-442c-b8a5-84d53f5ff75d/5_real_branch_list.png)

#####  What is the current *bug* behavior?

Delete a *wrong* branch, this can be a serious problem if the branch is _protected_ because it is deleted without the special confirmation form.

#####  What is the expected *correct* behavior?

Delete the correct branch you selected instead of another else.

######  Results of GitLab environment info

```  
root@329409c303d3:/# gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info

System information  
System:  
Current User:   git  
Using RVM:      no

SSH Clone URL:  ssh://git@git.imaginadesarrollo.es:2222/some-group/some-project.git  
Using LDAP:     yes  
Using Omniauth: yes  
Omniauth Providers: 

GitLab Shell  
Version:        13.18.0  
Repository storage paths:  
- default:      /var/opt/gitlab/git-data/repositories  
GitLab Shell path:              /opt/gitlab/embedded/service/gitlab-shell  
Git:            /opt/gitlab/embedded/bin/git  
```

####  Impact

1. Be able to delete a protected branch without confirmation.  
2. Delete wrong branch possibly leading to loss of information.

## Attachments

**Warning:** Attachments received through HackerOne, please exercise caution!

* [3_delete_branch.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/8777aa46-ddbf-4a4b-a192-6c84ef3fe17c/3_delete_branch.png)

title: Display a badge for project invite members
description:
# Overview

We recently added a new badge to the seat usage / billable members list that identifies billable members who are associated to the group via an "external" (to that group) shared group, here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/61366/diffs#3dcbcc79b02d356b3680761a34fa3cf7a8416ac4_187_187

We should also consider rendering a badge for when an external group is shared with a project, too, which means the `membership_type` will be `project_invite`, because those billable members also cannot be removed directly.

# Proposal

Add an additional badge/condition, here: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/d25b1266877ac91fd886001c41db6a55eca74f65/ee/app/assets/javascripts/billings/seat_usage/components/subscription_seats.vue#L204

which checks for `membership_type == 'project_invite'` and renders the badge accordingly

# Reason

This may reduce confusion for our customers as to why a user is listed in billable members, without any groups listed underneath them

# Screenshots

![Screenshot_2021-06-18_at_12.57.59](/uploads/f8df8e896a7b7572d65a5ca522ac7c65/Screenshot_2021-06-18_at_12.57.59.png)

# Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

What risks does this change pose to our availability? How might it affect the quality of the product? What additional test coverage or changes to tests will be needed? Will it require cross-browser testing?

Please list the test areas (unit, integration and end-to-end) that needs to be added or updated to ensure that this feature will work as intended. Please use the list below as guidance.
* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

Frontend specs should be written for the badge display.  When the account is "Group Invite", ensure the correct badge appears.  Same for "Project Invite".

title: How to run go get off a Geo secondary
description:
<!--

* Use this issue template for suggesting new docs or updates to existing docs.
  Note: Doc work as part of feature development is covered in the Feature Request template.

* For issues related to features of the docs.gitlab.com site, see
     https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-docs/issues/

* For information about documentation content and process, see
     https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/ -->

### Problem to solve

As `go get` uses Git repos to create packages, it should be possible to `go get` off a Geo secondary, and so reduce load on the primary.

Purpose of this issue is to flesh out how to do this, with a view to documenting it.

Bug issues should be raised if, in the progress, we reproduce it not working.

[GitLab team members can read more about potential challenges in a customer's ticket](https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/218690).

### Further details

<!--
* Any concepts, procedures, reference info we could add to make it easier to successfully use GitLab?
* Include use cases, benefits, and/or goals for this work.
* If adding content: What audience is it intended for? (What roles and scenarios?)
  For ideas, see personas at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/ or the persona labels at
  https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/labels?subscribed=&search=persona%3A
-->

#### Workaround for top-level namespaces, or public subgroup-level namespaces

##### Git over SSH

To retrieve the go module contents through git+ssh, add the following to `~/.gitconfig`:

```
[url "git@secondary.example.com:"]
          insteadOf = https://primary.example.com
```

Or use the git config command directly: `git config --global url.git@secondary.example.com:.insteadOf https://primary.example.com`

You will need a valid SSH key added to GitLab, which will be used to fetch the contents from the secondary GitLab Geo site when you run `go get primary.example.com/top-level/package`.

##### Git over HTTP(s)

To retrieve the go module contents through git over HTTP(s), you need a valid access token configured in your `~/.netrc` for the secondary Geo site (as it will be used to retrieve the package):

```
machine secondary.example.com login USERNAME password PAT
```

You will then need the following in your `~/.gitconfig`:

```
[url "https://secondary.example.com"]
          insteadOf = https://primary.example.com
```

Or using the git config command directly: `git config --global url.https://secondary.example.com.insteadOf https://primary.example.com`

#### Workaround for private subgroup-level namespaces

Since subgroup-level (nested) namespaces can come in different forms, you need to be authenticated on the primary to "confirm" the exact project location (to avoid leaking project existence information).

This means, **in addition** to the configuration above, you will need to have the following in your `~/.netrc`:

```
machine primary.example.com login USERNAME password PAT
```

If using HTTP(s) to clone from the secondary as well, you need to configure the PAT for both Geo sites, so your `~/.netrc` will look like:

```
machine primary.example.com login USERNAME password PAT
machine secondary.example.com login USERNAME password PAT
```

### Proposal

<!-- Further specifics for how can we solve the problem. -->

In this issue, we need to document the workarounds necessary before &1528 is released.

After &1528, things should work better. We'll just want to test `go get` usage, and then simplify the docs.

### Who can address the issue

<!-- What if any special expertise is required to resolve this issue? -->

### Other links/references

<!-- E.g. related GitLab issues/MRs -->

title: Dark Mode: Code Block in Test Report Details has bad colors

title: Add automated tests for python-3.9 in gemnasium-python analyzer
description:
### Proposal 

Now that [Temporary container for 3.9 python](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/328446) has been completed and we're publishing `python-3.9` images for `gemnasium-python`, we need to add automated tests to ensure that the `python-3.9` images actually contain `python 3.9`.

### Implementation plan

<details>
<summary>Expand for previous implementation plan</summary>

1. Add a new test to the [Secure Test Project Orchestrator](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/quality/ci/secure-test-project-orchestrator)
1. In the new test, execute the following and ensure that the version returned matches `Python 3.9.x`: 

   ```
   docker run -it --rm registry.gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python:2-python-3.9 /bin/bash                                         
   root@b6595b9802e6:/# python --version
   Python 3.9.5
   ```

</details>

1. Add a new rspec test to `gemnasium-python`, using the [`with no project`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/9ce00d783cac7a74957329b99514413cf30a35dd/spec/image_spec.rb#L13) test as a starting point
1. This test will do the following:

   1. Run the Docker image defined by `TMP_PYTHON_IMAGE`
   1. Execute the `python --version` command within the context of the above image
   1. Check the returned value to ensure that it matches `Python 3.9.*`

See [here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python/-/merge_requests/110#note_603740026) for more details.

/cc @gonzoyumo @fcatteau @NicoleSchwartz

title: Recommend reviewing the corresponding review guidelines for Product Intelligence related MRs
description:
Following up https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/329618, we need to make sure users check our review guidelines when needed, especially the "The merge request **author** should" section.

This would cover updating the [Snowplow Event Dictionary](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/snowplow/dictionary.html) whenever a Snowplow event is added, modified, or removed.

Using ~"Danger bot" we could remind users to check if an update is needed. This would be as simple as adding an attention message alongside the one we currently have.

<details><summary>The one we currently have :eyes:</summary>
![image](/uploads/bdba984adf9075bb83266747abb52cad/image.png)
</details>

### Message proposal

```
For the following files, a review from the [Data team and Product Intelligence team](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/growth/product-intelligence/engineers/-/group_members?with_inherited_permissions=exclude) is recommended.

[files_list]

Please check the [Service Ping review guidelines](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/usage_ping/review_guidelines.html) or the [Snowplow review guidelines](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/snowplow/review_guidelines.html), as corresponding.
```

title: Limit changing the security policy project to project owners
description:
<!--
Implementation issues are used break-up a large piece of work into small, discrete tasks that can
move independently through the build workflow steps. They're typically used to populate a Feature
Epic. Once created, an implementation issue is usually refined in order to populate and review the
implementation plan and weight.
Example workflow: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/threat-management/planning/diagram.html#plan
-->

## Why are we doing this work

We have gotten additional feedback from customers and prospective customers since we completed our first MVC for security policies.  As a result, we need to modify the permission requirements for creating, modifying, or deleting the link between the production project and the security policy project.

Currently, anyone with `Maintainer` or higher permissions on the development project can make these edits.  This needs to be changed to only allow project `Owners` to make these changes.

For reference, the original requirements are [here](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5329#permissions-and-security)

<!--
A brief explanation of the why, not the what or how. Assume the reader doesn't know the
background and won't have time to dig-up information from comment threads.
-->

-->

<!--
Steps and the parts of the code that will need to get updated. The plan can also
call-out responsibilities for other team members or teams.

e.g.:

- [ ] ~frontend Step 1
  - [ ] `@person` Step 1a
- [ ] ~frontend Step 2

-->

- [x] ~backend introduce new permission `update_security_orchestration_policy_project` `ee/app/policies/ee/project_policy.rb` to enable `:security_orchestration_policies` only for `:owner_access`:

```ruby
      rule { security_orchestration_policies_enabled & can?(:owner_access) }.policy do
        enable :update_security_orchestration_policy_project
      end
```

- [x] ~backend add additional check for `assign` method in `Security::PoliciesController` to allow assigning project only when user has permission to `:update_security_orchestration_policy_project`,
- [x] ~frontend disable dropdown when user cannot `:update_security_orchestration_policy_project` (modify `ee/app/views/projects/security/policies/show.html.haml` file to check for this permission and disable dropbox when it is missing)
![image](/uploads/6bfd8e02041b63f0a17fa2ff28749be6/image.png)
- [x] ~frontend In the policy list, next to the `New policy` button, show a `Edit Policy Project` button to project owners.
![edit policy project](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/7e3268b1c80ab0d391a1ef08cce4203d/image.png)
